Kerr Scott]] | term_start = 1945 | term_end = 1949 | birth_date = {{birth date|1891|10|17}} | birth_name = Robert Gregg Cherry | birth_place = South Carolina | death_date = {{death date and age|1957|6|25|1891|10|17}} | death_place = | nationality = | spouse = | party = [[North Carolina Democratic Party|Democratic Party]] | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = [[Duke University]] | occupation = | profession = | religion = }} '''Robert Gregg Cherry''' (October 17, 1891{{spaced ndash}}June 25, 1957) was the [[List of Governors of North Carolina|61st]] [[Governor of North Carolina|Governor]] of the state of [[North Carolina]] from 1945 to 1949. ==Biography== Born in [[South Carolina]] near Rock Hill, Cherry grew up in [[Gastonia, North Carolina]] with relatives after the death of his parents. He earned bachelor's and law degrees at Trinity College (now [[Duke University]]). He organized and led a volunteer artillery company during [[World War I]]. Cherry served as [[mayor]] of Gastonia, as a member and speaker of the [[North Carolina House of Representatives]], as chairman of the [[North Carolina Democratic Party]] (1937â€“1940), and as a member of the [[North Carolina Senate]]. In Gastonia, it was joked that he was the best lawyer in town when sober, and the second-best lawyer in town when drunk.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=7k4L4hCzxWkC&pg=PA150&lpg=PA150&dq=%22gregg+cherry%22&source=web&ots=avAV1AQYg2&sig=SFLdnIvs7uMzkJ8EscRq6xDKAaM&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=8&ct=result Tar Heel Laughter By Richard Walser]</ref> In 1944, Cherry was elected [[List of Governors of North Carolina|governor]] as the last in a series of governors affiliated with the political machine of former Gov. [[O. Max Gardner]].<ref>Christensen, Rob. ''The Paradox of Tar Heel Politics''. 2008. UNC Press.</ref> Gov. Cherry inherited an economy facing material and labor shortages as a result of the ongoing [[Second World War]]. One of his primary focuses during his term was the improvement of mental health care at state-run facilities. [[Cherry Hospital]] in [[Goldsboro, North Carolina]], is named for him. Unlike other Southern Democratic governors, Cherry supported [[Harry S. Truman]] for re-election in [[United States presidential election, 1948|1948]].
